Scene 1
list.item: Complete equipment of the small marionette stage with figures of Pierrette, Pierrot, Harlequin, ropes to manipulate figures, curtain, footlights, steps up to marionette platform, etc., etc.,
Fancy gilt tables, settee, chairs, etc., etc.

div.head:
-----
ACT I
PLACE: New Orleans.
TIME: About 1780.
SCENE: The Place d'Armes.
div.stage: A broad open space with the levee at back. There is a path along this levee bordered on both sides by tall trees, some of which are draped with the gray Southern moss. There is just a glimpse of the Mississippi between these trees. Along the levee from time to time as act progresses, people of various nationalities past. Mexicans, Indians, Spaniards, Negroes, etc. At extreme L. is an arcaded street in which are booths for flower sellers, cake and confectionary - sailors, etc. Over this arcade are the high latticed windows of dwellings in old Creole style. There is a door at L. into one of these houses. At right is the getaway entrance to the St. Louis Cathedral. Up stage in centre is a large fountain. The top of the fountain is in the form of a large urn. The pedestal leading from the basin to the urn must be large enough for a person to stand up in. The fountain is dry.
DISCOVERED: At rise of curtain it is just dawn. The sky shows crimson and gold over the river. Some BEGGARS are asleep at base of fountain. The music is soft and low.

sp.speaker: Night Watchman
sp.p: Five o'clock and a fine clear morning. All's well.

div.stage: (BEGGARS bestir themselves and sit up yawning. LAMPLIGHTER comes in and placing his little ladder against side of house, exstinguishes lantern. SACRISTAN comes shuffling across stage and with great key unlocks the door of cathedral. FLOWER GIRLS' VOICES off L. At entrance of FLOWER GIRLS the sun breaks forth and the stage becomes bright)

lg.l: Jessamine. Jessamine and roses.
Rose of May. Blushing posies.
Jessamine. Jessamine and roses.
Fresh flowers, sweet flowers. Roses. Flowers.

div.stage: (CHORUS enters in twos and threes forming little groups. MAN enters with donkey L.U. baskets on donkey, filled with flowers which he sells to flower girls)

lg.l: Come, come, come for the morning is breaking.
Haste, haste, haste, for the day is awaking.
Youth, life, love, everywhere,
Garlands of roses rare,
Fragrance upon the air shaking.
Come, come, haste. Sweet, sweet, sweet. Now 'tis springtime enthralling.
Peep, peep, peep, now the love birds are calling.
Cull your flowers, while you may,
Short ah. Too short the day.
Paroquettes. Paroquettes.
Petals will fade away falling.
Paroquettes, paroquettes. Happy fortunes telling,
Fresh figs, oranges, sugar cane. Sugar cane. ---
Come here, I'll buy.
Don't pass us by.
Come, clear the way, clear out I say,
You foolish vendors crying
We have to sweep the dust away,
We have no time for buying.
We have to work to clear the way,
The casket girls come today,
To make all fresh and fair and gay we're trying.
Here they come the convent maids,
So demure and shy
Creole beauties every one,
See them passing by.
Downcast lashes, lips demure
Stops precise and staid.
Oh la la oh la la.
I wouldn't be a convent maid.
Oh la la. Oh la la
I wouldn't be a convent maid.
There's Mamselle de Frontenac,
And Mamselle Rose Marie,
Creole beauties everyone,
High nobility.
Looking never right or left,
To smile they are afraid,
Oh la la Oh la la.
I wouldn't be a convent maid.
Paroquettes, Paroquettes. Happy fortunes telling.
Sugar cane. Sugar cane.
Clear the way -- clear out I say.
Oh come, come, come, for the morning is breaking,
Haste, haste, haste, for the day is awaking.
Youth, life, love, everywhere.
Garlands of roses rare
Fragrance upon the air shaking.
Sweet, sweet, sweet, now 'tis Springtime enthralling.
Peep, peep, peep. Now the love birds are calling.
Cull your flowers while you may
Short, ah, too short the day.
Petals will fade away, falling.

div.stage: (At close of chorus enter from R.1.E. ETIENNE GRANDET, the son of the Lieutenant-Governor. He is a young man of very elegant manners and dress. Full of the gallantry and extreme courtesy of a beau of the times. He is supposed to be merely a social butterfly but is in reality the pirate Bras Pique, whose band of buccaneers is the terror of the whole coast)

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Monsieur Etienne. Welcome back. Welcome home. (Girls rush forward and greet him)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah, Felice, Nanette, Fanchon. And how goes everything in Little Paris?

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: Oh, Monsieur. New Orleans no longer deserves the name of Little Paris with you away.

sp.speaker: Nanette
sp.p: Will Monsieur wear a rose?

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: No. No. My jessamine.

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: Ah no. The Fleur de Lis --

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.stage: (Taking the Fleur de Lis and putting it in his buttonhole)
sp.p:
Surely the flower of France, since I am so loyal a subject
of his gracious Majesty. Come, what is the news in Little Paris? What fortunes have been lost at dice? Who won the lottery? Who has stolen whose sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: Oh, Monsieur. There is no scandal when you are away.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Rather a back-handed compliment, my dear.

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: But such excitment -- Bras Pique, the pirate is abroad again.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Nanette
sp.p: He has scarcely allowed one ship to come safely in harbor since you sailed.

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: And Monsieur, the Place d'Armee is haunted.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Haunted, ha, ha!
Rather an open, airy place for a ghost.

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: It is true. You shall hear --- A voice in the air - singing -- But the voice comes from nowhere ---

sp.speaker: Nanette
sp.p: They say it is the spirit of someone who went down in the last vessel scuttled by Bras Pique.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ha, ha! Nonsense.

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: But 'tis true, Monsieur. Everyone has heard it. The voice, so sweet -- so mysterious. It begins a melody and then dies away.

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: It goes like this --
sp.stage: (She hums the refrain of Marietta's dream melody)

lg.l: La, la, la, la, etc.

div.stage: (Knife grinder's bell can be heard off U.C.)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Someone is playing you tricks.

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: No. No. Even Pere Antoine has heard it. He has had prayers said.

sp.speaker: Knife Grinder
sp.p: Knives to grind! Knives and scissors to grind.

div.stage: (ADAH, Etienne's quadroon slave and mistress, opens lattice of window over arcade)

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Here! My shears. (Throws scissors to man, sees Etienne)

sp.speaker: Nanette
sp.p: We had better leave or we shall have our faces scratched for talking to him.

div.stage: (ETIENNE takes bunch of roses from NANETTE and throws them up to Adah)

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Oh Master, it has been so long -- I feared --

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You feared perhaps that I had been spliced to the yard arm by Bras Pique.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Oh no! Not you. Will you come in?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Presently.

div.stage: (ADAH goes in from balcony closing window)

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: Look, Monsieur. Pirates?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Nonsense! Just innocent sailors on shore leave. The Casquette girls are about to land and they are here for the fun.

sp.speaker: Fanchon, Felice, Nanette
sp.p: Oh we must see the Casquette Girls too.
Come, au revoir, Monsieur!

div.stage: (ALL throw kisses to him as they run off R.U.)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Au revoir!

sp.speaker: 1st Pirate
sp.p: Master Pique!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Not Pique here!

sp.speaker: 1st Pirate
sp.p: We cannot land our goods at Barataria.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: And what have I to do with you and your goods, my good fellow? (Goes toward house L)

sp.speaker: 1st Pirate
sp.p: But Master, Captain Richard Warrington, the American, guards the coast for mile around the storehouses.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: In faith, 'tis a pretty pass when a gentleman may be accosted in the streets by a pack of ruffianly buccaneers. I shall have to inform my father, the Lieutenant-Governor, of this state of affairs, I shall indeed.

sp.speaker: 1st Pirate
sp.p: But, Master -

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Enough. You know where you may see your master. And, Manuelo, as you value your ability to wear those pretty earrings, never let this happen again. Adieu!

sp.speaker: 2nd Pirate
sp.p: What did I tell you, Manuelo?

sp.speaker: 1st Pirate
sp.p: He is the Devil, Bras Pique! He fears nothing.

div.stage: (THEY go up to Knife Grinder and throw him their knives to grind)

sp.speaker: Town Crier
sp.p: Hear ye! Hear ye all. The King of France has sent a shipment of Casquette maids. All men desiring wives shall present themselves at the King's storehouse. Hear ye, hear ye. All men desiring to wed.

div.stage: (Sounds of CAPTAIN DICK'S MEN, FLOWER GIRLS, CITIZENS, etc. Enter U.L. street waving to Captain Dick's men as they enter. CAPTAIN DICK and HARRY BLAKE enter)

lg.l: Tramp! Tramp! Tramp! Along the highway.
Tramp! Tramp! Tramp! The road is free!
Blazing trails along the byway.
Courier de bois are we!
Tramp! Tramp! Tramp! Now clear the roadway.
Room room room the world is free
We're planters and Canucks,
Virginians and Kaintucks,
Captain Dick's own Infantry.
We've hunted the wolf in the forest,
We've raided the pirates at sea,
We have no indenture,
We're out for adventure,
As anyone plainly can see,
We've smoked the peace pipe with the Hatches
We've fought with the Sioux wild and free
We've laughed at all dangers,
We're known as the Rangers,
Harry Blake - my good comrades --

div.stage: (DICK sings chorus - MEN repeat. DICK and MEN repeat 3rd chorus together end of 3rd chorus, orchestra repeats chorus -- DICK'S MEN and FLOWER GIRLS and CITIZENS all exit R. and L.)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Tramp! Tramp! Tramp!
Silas! Silas!
sp.stage: (Enter SILAS SLICK R.U.E. Comes down R.C.)
sp.p: Go to palace at once. Present these letters to the Governor.
And ask when he will grant an audience to Sir Harry Blake and Captain Richard Warrington.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: And me?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: And why you?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Why me, he asks! Was it not understood that I was to serve you until - until, mark you - I could find an opportunity that will place me in the environment to which I have always been accustomed?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: And what good will it do you if I include you in the audience to the governor?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I want to hear everything that's going on. I'm a servant - but I'm a temperamental servant.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: One moment, my good man.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I am his good man -- for the present.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: If I mistake not, I am addressing Captain Richard Warrington.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: At your service, sir.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I am Etienne Grandet, the son of the Lieutenant Fovernor. You may present your letters in person. My father will receive you as soon as he has disposed of the King's casket maids.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Thank you, but my letters are to Governor Le Farge.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Governor Le Farge sailed last month on a private mission to France. My father is in authority meanwhile.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Oh in that case -- of course -- Silas, the letters.
sp.stage: (He takes letters from SILAS. To Etienne)
sp.p: We have permission on from your king to attempt the capture of this buccaneer, Bras Pique, who has made it a hazardous venture for English ships to bring us supplies.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Yes -- we will splice him with his own yard arm!

div.stage: (He tries to break into the conversation, each time THEY push him back)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Indeed? That is good news. I trust you may be successful. But is not New Orleans a strange place for an attack on this

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Oh, as to that, we are in New Orleans only for a few days. My men are looking for --

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: Trouble.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Trouble -- what kind? We can perhaps oblige.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: The worst trouble, wives.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: My friend here, is an acknowledged woman hater.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: You see, sir, he doesn't attract the ladies -- How I love the darlings. Why? Because they love me.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: No one addressed you, Silas.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Oh, very well.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: My lads have heard what fine wives the King's casket maids make, and when they learned that a fresh shipment was to be disposed of here in New Orleans, nothing would do but every one of them must run his head into the matrimonial noose.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: And let me tell you - to get caught in that noose is not nice.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Quiet!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Here you are, sir.
sp.stage: (He clamps his hand over his own mouth)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Is it the girls or the well filled caskets which the king sends with him that attracts the men?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: Sir. That is not a very gallant remark for a Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: No harm meant. You, I take it, are Irish?

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: Take it or leave it, I am.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: And I -- sir, am a rising American. Submerged at present, but looking for my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Indeed?
If you will excuse me, Messieurs, I will tell my father of your arrival.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: We shall be obliged.

div.stage: (SILAS, taking the bows for himself, bows respectedly in imitation of him as he goes off)

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: He bows too much. I don't like the French.

div.stage: (TOWN CRIER comes in R. as DICK and HARRY exit L)

sp.speaker: Town Crier
sp.p: Hear ye, hear ye, all men desiring wives -- the King has sent a vessel of Casket Maids -- to be disposed of at the King's storehouse -- Hear ye, hear ye! All men desiring wives!

div.stage: (He goes off R. as the music of CASKET MAIDS is heard)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I'd better get away -- Those poor fellows will never get wives if the girls once see me.

div.stage: (CASQUETTE MAIDS and MEN dance in and sing:)
No. 3 "I'M COMING HERE TO BE MARRIED."
(CASQUETTE GIRLS enter R.U. with caskets followed by MEN)

lg.l: I have broad lands and a cabin too,
I've a range well stocked with caribou,
I've a snug little nest big enough for two.
Taisez vous, taisez vous. That'll do.
We're coming here to be married, married, married,
We don't intend to be married, not by you!
The king has given us caskets fair!
Our small possessions are in there.
You'll have to show you're fair and square,
Taisez vous, taisez vous.
Oh maiden fair, oh maiden fair,
Won't you marry me?
Taisez vous, taisez vous, we'll see!
I'm from arcady, the mon' ben' lan' --
I'm from Kaintuck, you know that's grand,
I've a house, a cow, and a bit of land.

sp.speaker: Girls

lg.l: Taisez vous. That'll do.

sp.stage: (Repeat refrain - have a little dance and exit L.U. after Dick's men)

div.stage: (LIZETTE enters R.U. singing, "I'm Coming Here to be Married." INDIAN enters R.U. and crosses stage to L)

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Not a man has noticed me yet -- but the King guaranteed us all husbands -- and I'll sue him for break of contract -- if he doesn't make good.
Oh -- maybe that is mine!
Tessy vous!

sp.speaker: Indian
sp.p: Ugh!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Now I wonder what that means.

sp.speaker: Indian
sp.p: Ugh! Ugh!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: It must have a double meaning.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.stage: (Looking after INDIAN, who walks out, arms folded, head high in exaggerated dignity)
sp.p: Those Indians, the way they strut. You'd think they owned the country.
Hello, what's your name?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Lizette - and I'm looking for a husband.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: My name's Silas Slick - and I'm looking for a good offer.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Are your intentions serious?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: It depends - that casquette, the King gave you. Is it valuable?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.stage: (Taking out casquette and dangling it before him)
sp.p: Here it is -- but it's not to be opened until after the wedding.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: H-m-m - doesn't look as if there's much gold in it.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Is it the gold or me you're interested in?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: A little of both - with the gold running slightly in the lead.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I tell you what I'll do. I'll go to the storehouse and look over the crop of prospective husbands. If they're not any better than you - I'll come back and consider your proposal.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: But - wait - it was - I mean - that is - it wasn't a proposal - it was an investigation!

div.stage: (He follows HER out - both arguing ad lib)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Dear me! Florence, fold the umbrella straight and don't stop fanning! If I had known the amount of work I'd have to do I would never have accepted the post of Lieutenant- Governor!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah, Father!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: So you are back!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: As you see.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Did you have a - er - prosperous voyage to France?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: To France! Oh come, you need not keep up this pretense with me, old side partner!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Don't call me side partner. You know I don't like it.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: But you are, you know. I do all the work. You protect me as a loving father should and you get half the profits.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Ssh!
I don't know what you are talking about. A public official may receive presents but not profits.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ssh! Diplomacy, Father, diplomacy!
Ah, gentlemen!
Father, allow me to present Captain Richard Warrington and Sir Henry Blake.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: We are honored, sir. We have a warrant from your king to attempt the capture of Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: We shall need your signature.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: We must give them every assistance, Father.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Oh, assuredly. Assuredly! Bye and bye. At present, urgent affairs call me.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: In faith, Monsieur Bye and Bye will be of no great assistance to us.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You must be patient with my father, Monsieur. He has much on his mind. He is on his way to dispose of the girls whom the King has sent here to wed our settlers.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: Ah! Speaking of those Casquette girls - tell me - have you any news of the pretty little devil who escaped from them?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Escaped!

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: Yes! From Mozambique where we saw them land -- my friend here is dying for news of her.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Nothing of the kind. I noticed her because she was different from the others.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: Yes, she was a fiery Italian girl and when the little devil learned that every Casquette girl was obliged to choose a husband, she said she'd take Dick.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.p: Yes -- and when Dick politely refused her, she up and struck him across the face with her gloves.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Oh, it was nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: And in the night, what did she do but up and vanish through the keyhold like smoke.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: That's strange, but, gentlemen, if you will join me at Antoine's Inn -- he has a pretty daughter who may do as well.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I must find ledgings for my men first -- we will see you later, if we may.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: As you will, Messieurs!
sp.stage: (One hears MARIETTA singing very softly the dream melody)
(ETIENNE pauses. Looks about. The song dies away)
sp.p: Strange -- I thought I heard --

div.stage: (MARIETTA draws herself up to edge of urn and with a little sigh of relief, and a roguish laugh, sits on ledge of urn and sings:)
(The first verse and refrain sung on fountain)

lg.l: There are two little maidens that live in my heart,
And one is so good like dis!
She look comme ca, and she talk la la!
Like butter won't melt, I guess!
But so other Marietta
Dat's also me!
Has a temper so warm, it's torrid,
So when I am good,
I am very good indeed!
But when I am bad, I am horrid!
Naughty Marietta be good, say she,
Mais non! Say me!
Naughty Marietta, you should, say she,
Be good like me!
Naughty Marietta go home, say she,
Mais non! Non! Say me!
That naughty Marietta, she simply will not let her
Be good, as she should, oui! oui!
Come a time, to the Convent they send me straight off,
I'm not fond of dat, not me!
I say my prayer, well, mos' everywhere
And better than gold I be.
But de Naughty Marietta
Dat's also me.
Made dat convent so warm, 'twas torrid
Cause when she was good,
She was very good indeed;
But when she was bad, she was horrid.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Santa Maria! I am hungry!
sp.stage: (She xes stage to cake stand and buys some cakes from MAID, who comes from house after song -- DICK enters R.U., sees Marietta, stops in C. of stage)
sp.p: What now? If I pay in gold for everything -- soon there will be empty vacancy in the purse!
sp.stage: (She starts up stage, munching cake and comes face to face with Dick)
sp.p: Ah! You have followed me!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I have done nothing of the kind!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Well -- why not, then?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Why did you run away from the camp at Mozambique?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: For fear you make me to marry you!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I make you -- whatever gave you that idea?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You maybe take serious that little joke of mine at Mozambique? I only said that to gain time -- I would not choose you -- of all others.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Believe me, the incident is forgotten -- as for marrying, no thought is further from my mind.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: And me too!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I value my freedom.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Me too!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I am not interested in love - it's nonsense.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Me too!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: But you must marry. You have accepted the King's casket.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: I throw it overboard - long time ago. The Casket! Bah!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: What are you going to do?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You must find me another dress.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Certainly -- you must get me -- what you say -- a disguise.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: A disguise? I should say not.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Can I stay forever sitting in zat fountain like a bird on ze nest?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: But --

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: For hours I have nothing but fruit and cake -- it makes me sick -- yes. I must come out I must sing and dance with all these gay people! I like this Little Paris -- I shall stay!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: But --

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Accordingly -- you must arrange for me something!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I -- why should I --

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Who else? You are my friend -- it is arranged -- is it not?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It is not -- arranged!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Besides -- ze whole -- thing is your fault.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: My fault? why?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Because. Anyway it is. If you had not make me angry, oh but so angry, at Mozambique -- perhaps I don't know -- maybe I not run away.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Do you know, I should take you at once to the Governor.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: But you will not?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You are stupid, but not cruel!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Stupid?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Like all men, maybe a little more stupid. You will get me the little dress. What you say? Skin and fur from here down, like a boy -- mais the other part -- perhaps a little becoming wiz lace? Yes!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I'll do nothing of the kind.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, but if you could see how -- what you say -- attractive I am in zose things from here down like a boy! Come, it is arrange! I will be one of your soldiers. "Tramp! Tramp! Tramp!" and when I am tire', you can carry me!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It's preposterous!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Of course it is pre---- that word you say. So you will hide me until the casket vessel sails away and all is over.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I most certainly will not hide you!
Ssh! Someone is coming, quick!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh no! You will not hide me, my friend!

div.stage: (Enter LIZETTE with SILAS following from L.U.)

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I can't even find the storehouse. It seems I'm not wanted and not wanted badly.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: It may be my opportunity -- I'd risk it if she'd let me have a look in that casket.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Silas -- Silas!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Yes, Captain --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I want you to go and find an Italian named Rudolfo who has a Marionette Theatre on the Rue -- Rue Canondelet. Bring him here at once.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: A Marionette Theatre. This may be my opportunity. I always thought I'd be a good actor.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Right away, sir. (He exits L.U.)

div.stage: (DICK goes up to call Marietta, when LIZETTE, who has been sitting disconsolately aside on casquette, sees him)

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Oh! Maybe this is my Fate.
Ahem! Teasey vous! Teasey vous. You'll pardon me! I'm so impulsive. Are you in the market?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I? No! Go away!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Mercy! Remember I'm a nervous woman! You can at least direct me to the storehouse where they're giving out the husbands.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I cannot. I am strange here.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: My opinion is you'd be strange anywhere. I shouldn't have spoken to you at all if I had known you were a man of such an unsanitary character -- I bid you farewell forever!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Thanks.
sp.stage: (CAPTAIN DICK looks off L., watches her crossing stage R., goes up to fountain, and calls)
sp.p: Marietta! Marietta!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Boo! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You - er - are very childish.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: And you also, my friend.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I have no woman friends.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Well, I will take pity on you -- I will be your friend -- come now, say it --

div.stage: No. 5 - SONG: "NEVER, NEVER CAN BE LOVE"

lg.l: Captain Dick
Well, here's my hand, we're friends you see.
Certainlee. Certainlee!
You're sure you'll never make love at me?
No! No! You'll see!
You'll never try just to kiss my hand?
I'm not that foolish kind of a man.
Then I'm sure if you're sure
And I'm sure I'm sure,
That we mutually understand!
We'll call it bond platonic,
Or friendship tried and true,
We'll call it just good comradeship,
Or simply chums will do.
You may say I'm your side partner,
My claim all claims above,
But solemly swear!
Yes, solemnly swear!
It never, never can be love!
No! It never never can be love!

div.stage: (At the end of song, DICK takes MARIETTA and hides her in fountain. SILAS and RUDOLFO enter L.U.)

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Captain Dick -- I know a not a Captain Dick.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Captain, here's Rudolfo. May I go?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Yes, you have the day to yourself.
Ah, you are Rudolfo, the keeper of the Marionette Theatre in the Rue Canondelet.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Si, Signor, poor Rudolfo! Who loss da leeetle son Rafaello, so biga like dat-a, so dear-a like dis-a, bed-a like hell-a.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Exactly -- well, I bring you word of Rafaello!

sp.speaker: Rudlofo
sp.p: You bring me word of my Rafaello! Oh, Signor! Heaven bless you. Permit-a me to salute.

div.stage: (Attempt to kiss Captain Dick on cheeks)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: That will do!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Where is he, my Rafaello?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: He's safe enough at my father's plantation in Kentucky. He is my mother's page boy where he does nothing all day with infinite grace.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Does nothing-a. Ah! That-a would please my Rafaello! He no like - pulls de Marionetta. He no like-a da organ-a. He no like-a da monk. He damn poor Italian. Oh, Signor. Safe and happy. I am your slave! I kiss your hands, your feet.
sp.stage: (MARIETTA peeps from behind fountain. She comes down between Dick and Rudolfo)
sp.p: I am forever your slave. How can I serve you?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Your boy was just so tall.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Perhaps, yes.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: As I remember, this young lady is not unlike Rafaello?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh I see, I see!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You will take this girl. Give her proper clothing and announce that your son has returned.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh excellente! Excellente! I kiss your hands, your cloak! But your cheek -- no, never!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: I no understand.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: There are reasons why she must remain unknown in New Orleans for the present! She shall be your son!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Father!
Padre mio!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: But a girl - a my son?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Come, you said you would serve me!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: But -- but --

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: It is arrange! I am your son. Come, padre mio! Come to the theatre of the Marionette. Oh la la! You shall see -- I will -- pulla da marionette -- I will eata spaghetti -- I will even like-a da monk!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: But -- but --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You shall be well repaid, Rudolfo.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Yes, yes. My gold is almost gone, but my friend has plenty. You shall be well paid. Come, I must take off this dress.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Here! You may have my cloak.

div.stage: (Goes to fountain, gets cloak and puts it about MARIETTA)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, you are good! Come, padre mio!
Oh, one moment!
Oh, be not afraid -- I will not kiss the cheek -- listen -- closely -- now --

lg.l: Ah, sweet mystery of life in vain I seek thee,
Ah! to know at last the secret of it all,
All the longing, la la la!

div.stage: (She pauses and looks at him expectantly)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Can you not finish my melody?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Finish it?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You see that is a dream melody! I hear it -- so many times when I got to sleep -- and it has been foretold me, that only he shall claim my heart, who will have power to sing the answer to it!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Then why ask me?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, of course you cannot. Being only my friend you would not even try, eh?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I'd most assuredly will not try.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: No, of course, I could not expect -- You will not even try --Come, padre mio --
You will not even try?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: No -- come, padre mio.

div.stage: (Song dies away as CAPTAIN DICK stands listening)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Try! I should say not --

div.stage: (He starts to sing it - on exit. Goes off angrily, R.U.)
(As he exits, SILAS and LIZETTE reenter R.U. She is weeping noisily)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Sh! What are you laughing at?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I am not laughing.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: What is it then?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I'm such a nervous woman.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I wouldn't cry that way then if I were you.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: You can cry any way you like. This is my way. I can't help it if I'm historical.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Historical -- Are you so old as that?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Old! I'm only, only --

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Better hurry, Madam. Every minute makes it worse.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I should say it does -- Here I am verging on -- twenty, and would you believe me, I have never had a proposal.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I would believe you.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: At the boat -- where we landed, there was scores of men following each girl -- all but me. What's the matter with my face?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I don't know. Who did it?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: The King guaranteed husbands. If he hadn't I would never have come away so far from home and mother -- and lugging this heavy Casquette.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: It is heavy then.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Hands off.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Does it jingle when you shake it?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Of course, there's gold in it -- Would you marry me for my gold?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: For what other reason --- I -- I love you.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: You?! Why?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I don't know -- it just came over me.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: You are nothing but a servant.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Ah, but my bondage will not, cannot, last forever. I but await my opportunity. In the meanwhile I am in training.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: In training?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Yes, to be a pirate.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: A pirate. Mercy! Remember I'm a nervous woman.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: You see. My arm is already tabooded.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Tabooded!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Yes. See! I have the name of Bras Pique tabooded here with indelicate ink.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Are you Bras Pique?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Not yet. But some day -- with the help of Captain Dick -- we will scuttle his vessel. It will be my opportunity. I will take his place -- I shall buccaneer all over the seas. Bras Pique the Second!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Who would have thought it, a man like you.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Ah! But I am not what I seem.

div.stage: No. 6 - SONG - "I WISH I WAS ANYBODY ELSE BUT ME"

lg.l: I must have been changed in my cradle,
By my nurse or something like,
For I ain't turned out what I ought to be
And nothing seems to be right!
Mon Doo! Parblew! Mon chair!
That is a sad affair!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.stage: (Takes HER by the arm, goes R.)

lg.l: So sometimes I get to dreamin'
As a feller will you see,
Of the kind of a sort of a "me" I'd be,
If I wasn't the me that's me!
Mon Doo! Parblew! You speak,
The word, ah! Tres tragique!
I wish I was anybody else but me - anybody else would do
It's awful discouraging being me, when I ought to be you or you!
I tries to smile, but what's the use? It hits me with a slam!
When I get to thinking of the man I'd be, if I wasn't who I am!

div.stage: (SILAS has twisted up his drooping moustache and he struts about with all the braggadocin of a pirate - dances with LIZETTE - following - at end of dance, exits R.)
(After SILAS and LIZETTE exit, enter GOVERNOR and SECRETARY from convent)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Upon my word, Florence, you are very irritating, Just as I think my work is over for the day, you come to me with this tale of a missing Caasquette girl.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: But, your Excellency!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: How do you know there is one missing?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: While your Excellency was asleep at the Convent --

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Sleep! I never sleep -- I'm a servant of the people.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: While your Excellency was as -- I mean resting, - at the Convent - there came three survivors from the Italian vessel captured by Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Survivors! Why survivors!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: That's what I say, why survivors?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: They were marooned and escaped. They bring dispatches from the King of France.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Take off my hat when you mention the King.

div.stage: (Secretary takes off LIEUTENANT- GOVERNOR'S hat and replaces it)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Of what matters are these dispatches?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: A command to the Lieutenant-Governor to immediately return one Marietta d'Altena to France from whence she has escaped, having bribed a casket girl to give her the place.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: And of course it must be this important one who is missing?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: The Countess d'Altena! Why, that is one of the richest and most powerful families in Italy. We must find her ---

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: And of course something disagreeable is promised me if I fail to find this maid?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: You will fall under the King's displeasure.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Dear me -- dear me -- the things I shall have to answer for when the Governor returns.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: If he returns -- I do not think he will.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Hush! I'll not listen.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You must listen, Father. You hope to benefit by my plans. You must not shirk the responsibility.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Well - well?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: My men have marooned the Governor on the Isle of Pines. When the right moment comes, we shall announce Louisiana to be a Republic - we shall throw off allegiance to France ----

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Hush! Hush! This is no place -- besides -- I'll not take the responsibility -- I'll have enough to answer for -- if your schemes fall through.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You should get a whipping boy, Father.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: A whipping boy such as they had in the old times, to take upon themselves the punishments of royalty! Ha, ha! Just the things for you.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Did I not tell you to search every law and precedent to make things easier for me?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Yes, Excellency.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Then why have I never heard of this most convenient instituion of the whipping boy?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: The law is old, obsolete, I think.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I reinstate it. You shall find a whipping boy for me - if you don't I'll make you my whipping boy.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Oh dear, oh dear, where shall I get a whipping boy?

div.stage: (Runs up and down stage as if looking for something)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Have you lost something?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: I'm about to lose my position as Secretary to the Governor.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Secretary to the Governor.
This may be my opportunity. If you lose that position will you speak a word for me?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: What! Are you looking for something to do?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Then thank your lucky stars you met me.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: It must be easy -- some sort of a sitting-down position.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Providence led you to me.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I know. It's a great chance for you. I'm a rising American --

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: In the name of the Lieutenant-Governor I offer you the magnificent post of Whipping Boy.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I don't like the name. I refuse it.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Wait! Wait! Let me read to you the prerequisites which go with the post of Whipping Boy.
"The Whipping Boy shall receive three suite of fine marquisette embellished with gold braid."

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Real gold?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Eighteen karat. "He shall dine at the royal table and shall first taste of each delicate viand set before his royal master."

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Wait -- why first?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: In case the food be poisoned.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: And you call that a fine position?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Oh, but that will never happen.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I don't want the position. It sounds almost dangerous.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: But listen -- I have not read all.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: You've read enough.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: "His wife shall sit next the Grand Marshall."

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I don't know about that. What kind of a person is this Grand Marshall -- Maybe I couldn't trust my wife. I don't think much of this position - Let's call it off.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: "In addition the Whipping Boy shall receive the sum of ten thousand francs per annum."

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Ten thousand francs. Well, maybe I could just pretend to do that tasting you spoke of. How often does this annum business come around?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: You may draw on the Treasury at your need.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Somebody's going to wake me up in a minute.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Do you accept?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Do I accept? It is the opportunity I have been waiting for.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Then present yourself at the palace ---

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Wait! I have a sudden thought. What is it I have to do for all this?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Oh, a mere detail; you accept the responsibilities of the family.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: But suppose I have no family. I can't guarantee that.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Not your family. The Governor's family.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Support the Governor's family on ten thousand francs per - what is it?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Oh no, no! You simply -- You see, if anyone of his family should commit any crime - er, I mean little discretion - you answer for it in your person.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: In my person! That's where the whipping comes in. Thank you for wasting my time. That's not the kind of a position I'm looking for.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Oh, there'll be no whipping, I'll promise you!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: There'll be no whipping, I promise you. Good day.

div.stage: (ETIENNE enters for a house L. followed by ADAH)

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Etienne - Etienne, Master!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: You've been away so long ---

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Only a month.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: They might know, they might suspect.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Suspect what?

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: That you are Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You say that so often, my dear, I shall begin to believe you are right.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: You no longer care for me, you no longer love me - am I not the same?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You give me too warm a welcome, try indifference for once it may attract. There, there, Adah I was only joking - forgive me - But love should be free, you make it a bondage. Au revoir, Mademoiselle.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Ah 'tis true - it is as I feared! He no longer loves me - he has wearied of me.

div.stage: (SILAS enters from R. - he throws off his cloak and his hat - throws them on fountain rim - he struts about. As he is doing this - some GIRLS enter R. and stand looking at him fearfully)

sp.speaker: Nanette
sp.p: Do you think he can be Bras Pique?

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: 'Twould be like his daring. See! He wears the red bonnet.
Monsieur, have you letters on your arm?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Ah ha! You have been reading my letters.

div.stage: (He pulls up his sleeve displaying arm with tattooed letters)

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: 'Tis he! 'Tis Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I've killed many thousands of mosquitoes.

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Mosquitoes!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Mousquetiers, I mean. Listen! Hist! I am Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Wait! Fear me not! I am a gentle creature with the ladies. But - on the seas - I wade in blood!

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Ugh! Silas Pull twenty fathoms deep lie dead man's bones! And in my treasure chests are gold and jewels. Jewels to adorn pretty maids like you -- and you -- and you!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Ah ha! Take care! Beware!
In dead of night my pirate band shall come to carry off to coral isles - all the pretty maids of New Orleans.

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Oh help! Bras Pique! Help!

div.stage: (They run off L. and R.1. and U.)

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Well, I'm ready to entertain your proposal, young man.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: My proposal! Caramba! Sapristi!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Mercy! Remember I'm a nervous woman!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Leave me, woman, leave me!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: But I can't get a husband. They're all given out and --

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Peace, woman. I have made my choice. I see my opportunity! I shall be wedded to nothing but the sea!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Mercy! The sea's so wet! Anyway somebody's got to marry me!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: That's his problem! Leave me, woman! Leave me! Do you hear! Caramba! Sapristi.

div.stage: (He approaches her fiercely, showing his teeth)

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Mercy! Help!

div.stage: (She starts to run and drops casquette. It jingles)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Wait! I'll give you one chance, woman, the casquette. Open it.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I can't. The King's commands --

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Open it - I say! If its contents are what I surmise, you shall be Madam Buccaneer!
sp.stage: (LIZETTE with trembling fingers starts to open casquette)
sp.p: Ah ha! Gold! Gold!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I wouldn't do it, only I'm dying of curiosity myself!
"A grant of land on the Mi-si-si-pi River!"

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Tut! Tut! Get to -- the gold! The gold!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.stage: (Hastily throwing other papers and things out, eagerly feels in bottom of casquette and brings up three or four gold pieces)
sp.p: Can this be all!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: What a stingy king! So long.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Wait! Wait! You promised....

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Well, you see. I forgot -- about the tobacco -- you know every man who would a Casquette girl must deposit a hundred pounds of tobacco at the storehouse.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: And you have none?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Not a pipe full.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Here -- take the gold. Buy the tobacco. Hist! Not a word to anyone - I will await you at the storehouse.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: That's right, you wait -- Don't stir until I come for you!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Not a word to anyone. Hurry, buy the tobacco. I will be yours, my bethrottled!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: She did it herself! It's her own fault. But it's my fault if she ever sees me again.
sp.stage: (He puts gold in pocket and starts toward R)
sp.p: Now, where did I put my cloak?
sp.stage: (Sound of voices and cries off L)
sp.p: Ah! Doubtless the girls returning to hear my merry tales of piracy!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Oh Si, my Si! The girls have told the guards you are Bras Pique, the pirate! They are coming to arrest you!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Arrest me! My cloak! My hat! Where are they? Run, find my master -- Find Captain Dick. He'll tell them I'm no pirate.

div.stage: (Business of rushing about to find hiding place)

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: You can't hide here.

div.stage: (THEY rush up stage. LIZETTE hides SILAS in fountain)
(PEOPLE run in shouting: "Bras Pique! Drown him! Hang him!")

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Here! Here! What does all this mean!

sp.speaker: Nanette
sp.p: Oh, Monsieur! Bras Pique the pirate!

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: He was here. We saw him!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Nonsense! Let us have no more talk of pirates! Listen --
It's the Italians -- Come! Sing! Dance! Be merry! Or I shall think have landed on the shores of some Yankee town and not my gay New Orleans!

div.stage: (Music of organ comes nearer and FELICE runs in)

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: What do you think? Rudolfo has found his little son!

div.stage: (ALL rush to entrnace and great RUDOLFO as he enters with his DAUGHTERS and MARIETTA)

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Vive the Italians! Vive Rudolfo!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah, fine song, Rudolfo, and well sung! Who is this lad, your son?

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Yes my leetle son-a, she has returned.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah, my little lad, so you have returned to your padre.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, yes, Monsieur. Now I like-a to pull-a de Marionetta. I like de spaghetti. I even like-a de monk.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah ha, the lad has wit.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Ah, Rudolfo, Rafaello.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You know the lad?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Ah, Captain Dick, he is my friend. He find poor Rafaello to be make roast pig by the Indians. He save me --he bring me back to Padre mio. I kiss his hand, his cloak -- his cheek.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Never mind -- that will do --

div.stage: (The GOVERNOR and SECRETARY enter from R.U.)
(EVERYONE bows - CITIZENS take off hats to the Governor)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Dear me, dear me.
I give it up! I give it up! How can I look the Casquette Girls over to find the missing one, if someone doesn't bring them to me!
Here -- call the people to order!

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Silence! Attention all! The King of France offers ten thousand francs --

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Ten thousand francs?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: The King of France offers ten thousand francs for the return of Marietta, Contessa d'Altena, -

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: A Contessa?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Who in the disguise of a Casquette Girl escaped from France. Said Marietta d'Altena is small, dark and has a voice of rare beauty, is continually singing an unfinished melody. Here follow a lot of notes.

div.stage: (Attempts to sing melody in cracked voice)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Allow me --

lg.l: La la la la la.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: The melody! The haunting melody. The Casquette girl must be here. The fountain - ten thousand francs! We will find her!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: There goes Silas!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: 'Tis Bras Pique! Bras Pique! Seize him! Catch him!
sp.stage: (TWO MEN seize SILAS - He is struggling to get away - they force him to his knees)
sp.p: Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: No - no! Don't! I was only playing a pirate to please the girls. I am no pirate.
O, save me! Save me! I'll do anything -- I will be your Whipping Boy. O, save me, Governor, save me!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Let him alone, he is my Whipping Boy.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Whipping Boy?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Why, this is my man, Silas.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: No longer. The yoke of servitude - I throw it off. This is my opportunity!

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.stage: (Entering from R.U. coming down, seeing Marietta)
sp.p: Well, by all that's holy, this is the runaway Casquette girl.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: No - no, Padre mio --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Take her away.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: No. No. No Casquette. This lady is my son.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah -- so this lady is your son, eh! I thought the voice too sweet for a lad. Marietta, Contessa d'Altena!

div.stage: (During this Finale DICK keeps urging Rudolfo to get away with Marietta. A sound of convent bells heard off. ETIENNE, GOVERNOR, and all the CITIZENS turn and kneel down at the convent gate, while organ is playing)
(DICK urges RUDOLFO to make his escape with MARIETTA. RUDOLFO and MARIETTA exit L.U. DICK and his FOLLOWERS cover their retreat stopping ETIENNE and the PEOPLE at the point of their guns)
