div.stage: Front Scene in Marionetta Theatre. Dark room with doors Right and Left. Centre of stage the Marionette stage with the figures of Pierrot and Pierette, Harlequin, etc., upon it. There is a little curtained window at Right of Centre.
DISCOVERED: At rise, RUDOLFO in front of platform instructing MARIETTA, who is on stage, how to pull the wires for the Marionettes.

lg.l: Turn-a like dat-a Pierrette, just so,
Bow to de lady Signor Pierrot,
Santa Maria! No! No! No! No!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: How he is stupid, your friend Pierrot.

div.stage: (A little dance of the Marionettes done very awkwardly while RUDOLFO stands aside beating time)

lg.l: Come, dat is better, Signor Pierrot
Take de lady in arms like so?

sp.stage: (Two figures in attempt to embrace, fall in a heap)

lg.l: Santa Maria! No! No! No! No!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: How! He is crazy, your friend Pierrot!

div.stage: (Dance again, ending in a furious jumble of legs and arms, RUDOLFO tearing his hair)

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: It is alaways the same-a thing! You begin-a to learn-a de Marionettes, and you make-a it all the same joke!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: That's the point, padre mio! All the world's a joke! Oh, how I am happy for the first time in my life! I laugh!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: You are happy because you make-a three men miserable!
sp.stage: (MARIETTA takes tambourine from wall and practices throwing and catching it, dancing gaily about room as he talks)
sp.p: First me! I say to the peoples, my son-a she has returned. Then sudden you say -- No more boy's dress. I want be myself! Then for me to crack my brain to explain my sudden daughter!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: A daughter is best, Padre mio! It brings the customers! Now your theatre is crowded every night. How many costumes you have rented for the Quadroon Ball? They all come to see Marietta!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Then my good-a Capitaine Dick - and Monsieur Etienne, the son-a of His Excellency -- Now you flirt with both!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, Padre mio - I think I have my song --

lg.l: "Oh, sweet mystery of life!"

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: That song! Make-a me to go crazy!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, but try it. Padre mio -- Maybe you can finish him -- Then I love you, oh so desperately -- like fire!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Santa Maria forbid! We must practice some more with the marionettes - stop this talk about a songs.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: I will not practice any more. I am going to rest too - like-a dez marionettes - they never do no work themselves. Always somebody have to make them move.

div.stage: (Have PREMIER DANCERS enter dressed as Marionettes and do a dance. After dance enter)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.stage: (Look about, Sees no one about and call)
sp.p: Oh, Marietta.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Ah, Monsieur, it is more than kind that you should so often visit the house of poor Rudolfo and his unworthy daughter.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Come, Mademoiselle, have you not tired of his masquerade?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Masquerade?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: These mean surroundings are not fitting for you!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: I was never so happy -- I mean, I am used to it!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Come - why not announce your rank? You only postpone the inevitable day. At any moment your father will arrive from Italy and think how shall we account for your lodging here?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Ha! Ha! When the illustrious, the Count d'Altena arrives, you will see your mistake. How he will rave! What, this little brown maid, this child of the people my daughter?" He will think you are crazy, yes.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Oh well, I know there is no use trying to persuade you.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Still you try.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I give in for the present. I have come for a different purpose. I want you to come to the Quadroon Ball tonight.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: But I cannot - I have told you. Captain Dick he say no, it is no place for a very good girl like me.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Captain Dick knows nothing of our customs. Many of the finest women in New Orleans will be there -- masked, of course. So shall you!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Captain Dick, he is my friend. He say no! It is so naughty, that ball, he will not go himself!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Did he say that -- Strange! Adah - my own Adah has deserted me tonight to go with him!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: What! Captain Dick will go with Adah? Wait, I will go also.
Yes, I laid down the law to Rudolfo -- and Captain Dick -- I will go --

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: With me!?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Mais non -- with myself! (Exits door L.)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: She is a witch! What puppets we are, the strongest of us can be pulled about by a little weak woman like that.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.stage: (During the song he takes one of the Marionettes and setting it upon table, sings to it)

lg.l: Now why should a man who has courage to face
God, man and the devil, all three,
Give in to a bundle of satin and lace?
The answer is simple as simple can be!
For we men are but puppets, after all
As we laugh or we sigh or we sing:
Yo-ho, yo-ho, yo-ho!
If we creep or we crawl, if we stand or we fall,
You may gamble some woman is pulling the string!
Oh, a man is a man, do what he can,
Whatever his breed or birth!
And a maid is a maid and she isn't afraid
Of the biggest man on earth!
So if you're a fool and expect to rule
The woman you're planning to get,
Then by the old Harry, be sure when you marry
You marry a Marionette,
My boy,
Yes, marry a Marionette!

div.stage: (At finish of song, ETIENNE goes to door R. and starts to exit. ADAH suddenly confronts him, closing door, stands with back to it, glaring at Etienne)

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: So! You are here again!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: And you also!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: You - you love this girl -- you no longer love me --

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Oh come -- come -- Love -- that's a large word.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: You have asked her to go to the ball?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I have! And I told her to come early that she might see the sale of those slaves who have displeased their master by boring them with jealousy!!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: You dare not sell me!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Sell you! Not while you are so gentle, so sweet, so confiding, so trustful! Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Etienne!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Sell you? My sweet, never jealous companion. Never think it.
Good-bye! Good-bye!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Etienne! Etienne!

div.stage: (CAPTAIN DICK enters from curtains, goes over to door R., look out, turns to Adah - touches her on shoulder)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Adah!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Etienne!

div.stage: (She turns, grabbing DICK, thinking it is Etienne)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh - I - don't let me disturb you.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: I thought -- Oh -- let me go.

div.stage: (ADAH runs out door R. DICK embarrassed)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: She thought I was Monsieur Grandet!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: And I think you are Monsieur Liar!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Don't be angry.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Angry! Me! I! You may embrace anyone you please. What is it to me? I am in a beautiful mood. I have much to do before I prepare myself for the ball!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You promised me you would not go!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Me! I disremember! I am so forgetful. I disremember that promise.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: But I'm going to hold you to it.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.stage: (Taking feather duster, pushes it into CAPTAIN DICK's face)
sp.p: Now look you, Captain Dick, consider, I have never had one - what you say - a good time in all my life.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It is your own fault.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: My fault? Santa Maria! In Italy I was banished and sent away to a convent to learn to be a lady --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Where you should have stayed.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, my friend. Then you would never have seen me.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I could have survived. Your parents did exactly right. And I shall feel relieved when they come for you.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, very well, they will marry me to the old man so old, so ugly, with a long beard ---

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: We shall make it a condition of your safe return to France that they shall not compel you to marry.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Your condition! Pooh! That's what they think of conditions. And you - how will you feel when poor Marietta is married to the old one with a beard? And no one will find her dream song. Have you tried it lately, Captain Dick?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I have not given it a single thought!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: He has given it no thought! And this is my friend, my sworn friend! Monsieur Etienne he try like the mischief - and he is no friend!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Ah, Rudolfo!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Ah, Signor, you come in time. She drive-a me crazy.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: She'd drive anyone crazy.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: How soon-a you think-a they come to take-a her away?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It will not be long, Rudolfo.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: What you think? Not long - and they smile. Barbara! Oh --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Oh come! Come! I didn't mean to hurt you.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Figlio mio, do not-a weep-a.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: No one love me. My padre, he does not love me!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Oh yes, like-a my soul -- better than my daughters. Yes -- when you are good --

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: I am always good. I like pulla de marionette-a! I like de spaghetti, I even like da monk. Not like Rafaelo damn poor Italiano. Still you do not love me.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Ah, but yes, I love you!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Capitaine Dick, he does not love me. -- Or do you?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I certainly do not!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh terrible - miserable - my friend will not love me! (Pretending to cry)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I like you -- I like you very much.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Like - ah, miserable -- you like potatoes!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Come, come, Marietta, don't cry, I'll try to - to more than like you!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: He will try! Oh, poor Marietta, he cannot love me, but he will try --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: If you'll stop crying, I'll do anything.

sp.speaker: Marieta
sp.p: Oh! He won't give me one friendly little kiss. Oh - oh --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I will if I must.

div.stage: (Puts arms about her to kiss her)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.stage: (Jumping away and laughing in his face)
sp.p: Ha! Ha! Ha! Not tonight, my friend. Oh, you big stupid! Save your kisses for Adah!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It's your fault, you spoil her.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: But -- but --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: She should have been put in the care of the nuns. I have made a mistake allowing her freedom.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: I told you!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You did not, no one told me. Besides how can one cage fire or quicksilver! She - is -- oh, how glad I will be when her parents come for her.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: I cannot be glad, if they take her away - I --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Take her away! Oh well, it must be! And look you, Rudolfo, we are responsible for her. She must not go to the ball tonight.

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: But certainly, I lock her up tight.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Lock her up? Poor child - but this is her own fault -- yes, it must be --

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: My daughter shall take away everything -- all her clothes. We will keep her safe.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You will be well rewarded, Rudolfo, you shall see!

div.stage: (Goes out door R., followed by RUDOLFO)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Lock me up! Oh, the miserable! No, no, if he have spoke nice, maybe then I not go. But lock me up! Right away -- quick I go!
Come, Pierrot! You shall aid me. La - la - la!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Never fear, Captain Dick, I'll keep her safe for you.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Not for me, stupid!

sp.speaker: Rudolfo
sp.p: Oh no, for her father!
Marietta! Marietta!
"La! la! la! la!" Oh, the old fool, me!
Ah, she hides to tease-a her old padre.
sp.stage: (Goes over to curtains. Pulls them aside, looks in)
sp.p: Not here! Ah, the window - perhaps!
My cloak! My hat!
I lock all the doors. I go out and search for Marietta at once.

div.stage: (He exits hurriedly out of door R. locks door after him)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p:
Oh ho! Signor Pierrot! I shall go to the ball! No! But
he will go with Adah!

div.stage: (MARIETTA comes down steps, dances to door L., finds it locked -- dances to door R., finds that also locked -- sees window -- goes to window, takes domino from stool in front of window, throws kisses to marionette on small stage and exits window)

SCENE: The ballroom before the opening of the ball. A large room with pillars at L. into larger dancing room. Stairs centre. Balcony at back upstairs with large windows opening onto a veranda. Doors into room upstairs at R. Entrance from street in centre under balcony.
AT RISE: MEN are seated at tables dicing and playing cards. All elegant swaggering GENTLEMEN, full of life and excitement. Creole high society.

lg.l: Gambling, gambling, racing, dicing,
Life's a sort of gamble if you look at it that way
We have no time for melancholy
We're votaries of mirth and folly.
New Orleans' Jeunesse dores.
I'll take you.
I'll double!
I'm with you! (Throws dice)
It's yours!
Look up! Buck up! Pay! Pay! Pay! Pay!
Gambling, gambling, racing, dicing,
Life's a sort of gamble if you look at it that way
We have no time for melancholy
We're votaries of mirth and folly.
New Orleans' Jeunesse dores.
My cotton!
My mistress!
I'll take you! (Throws dice)
You've won!
Look up! Buck up! Pay! Pay! Pay!

div.stage: (End of Men's Chorus - enter ETIENNE U.R. He is very gorgeously dressed - as are all the OTHERS. MEN spring up and salute him)

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Ah! Monsieur Etienne!

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Vive, Monsieur Etienne!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Thanks, Messieurs! Come! Off with the tables! Clear the room! The ladies are arriving. -- I'll bet you'd play dice on the tombs of your grandsires.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I'll take you! Tonight, after the ball, in the churchyard!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I'll go you --
If someone will carry you there. For it's my will, as Master of Ceremonies, that no man shall leave here tonight who can attend on his feet!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: His Excellency, the Lieutanant-Governor.

div.stage: (The LIEUTENANT-GOVERNOR enters, followed by SECRETARY and SILAS, as Whipping Boy. SILAS is completely transformed -- is magnificently dressed, wears a sword with which he is constantly becoming entangled)

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Vive, the Lieutenant-Governor!

div.stage: (LADIES enter from R. and L. through centre door top and take position on stairs)
(LADIES and GENTLEMEN are talking low - a little laughter here and there)

sp.speaker: Lieutenant-Governor
sp.p: When does the entertainment begin?

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: At once, Excellency.

div.stage: (ALL laugh and continous talking, paying no attention to Silas)
No. 14 SONG -- "THE LOVES OF NEW ORLEANS"

lg.l: We are the loves of New Orleans,
Its languour, its glow, its fire,
We wear the badge of the red, red rose
With its fragrance of desire.
We are the loves of New Orleans,
Sweet, slumbrous flowers of night,
We drive the cares of the day away
In our gardens of delight.
Angelique! Felice! Veronique! Annice!
You drive the cares of day away in your gardens of delight.

div.stage: (MUSIC for SPANISH GIRLS - enter from C. door)

lg.l: Oh hola, we dance La Cachuca!
Castanets sounding so gay!
The bright eyes of each senorita
Shall drive every trouble away!
Oh hola, we dance La Cachuca!

div.stage: (Orchestra repeats - THEY do a Spanish dance)
(SAN DOMINGO GIRLS take position on stairs. AS SPANISH GIRLS dance -- enter door from above)

lg.l: Belles from San Domingo!
Island far away!
Lovely San Domingo!
Island far away!

div.stage: (SAN DOMINGO GIRLS do slow posture dance)
(Music for FRENCH GIRLS -- enter from C, door)

lg.l: You'll plainly see, we're from Paris,
We have ze air, we have ze smile,
Regardes vous, we have ze style!
We know a thing or two we do!
La Belle Marie, Annette, Frou Frou!

div.stage: (THEY do a very gay dance, and then the entire CHORUS goes into refrain of the first song. Repeat once:)

stage.hi: "WE ARE THE LOVES OF NEW ORLEANS"

div.stage: (At conclusion of ensemble, GIRLS do cakewalk, dance, exit in twos into ballroom)
(On encore, repeat cakewalk for Girls only -- MEN remain off)
(Meanwhile, the GOVERNOR and SECRETARY have been seated on settee)
(After encore, LIZETTE appears on landing in Centre door)

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Is it possible -- do my eyes deceive me?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: They do! I am not what you are looking for!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Ah, that voice - my rising American! I knew I would find you at last!

div.stage: (She throws her arms around his neck)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Your Excellency - I demand protection from this woman.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Bye and bye.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Bye and bye -- it's now I need it!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I waited for you, Si -- I waited at the storehouse. You never came.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Who is this female?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I am a casquette maid, sir --

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: She's home-made--

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: If you are a casquette maid, why are you not wed and out of New Orleans?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Ask him!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: You see, your Excellency, what she wants is to be sent back to France.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: I don't. I want a husband. And I want him quick. Husbands were guaranteed.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Did the King see you when he gave that guarantee?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: His envoy did, and he said there'd be a perfect rush in my direction.
sp.stage: (The GOVERNOR gets ups and starts to L)
sp.p: Wait, Your Excellency, this man took my gold.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: You gave it to me!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: He made me open the casquette. He took my gold to buy tobacco. Where is it now?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Gone up in smoke.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: This is serious! Well! Well! This must be looked into -- but not now, bye-and-bye--

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Bye-and-bye --- That's always the way it is with me. I am always waiting, but such is the beauty of my nature that I never give up hope.

div.stage: No. 14 SONG -- "IN THE SWEET BYE AND BYE"

lg.l: I am a maid, a pretty maid,
A dainty touch-me-not,
No man can say that he from me
The slightest favor got!
Though hosts of suitors, mad with love,
Pursue me day and night,
I calmly say,
"Stay, villain stay!"
I wait for Mr. Right!
Bye-and-bye, Bye-and-bye,
Don't meet your troubles coming,
And perhaps they'll pass you by.
No kiss has flushed this brow of snow,
No touch profaned my treasures' flow,
But that's all right, because I know
That someone's going to love me in the Sweet Bye-and-Bye!
I don't deny, I burn to be
The pet, the joy, the life,
Of some brave man who would make me
His lawful wedded wife;
But if a wretch should dare to breathe
A word that wasn't right!
I'd give a whack!
Say, "Villain, back!
I wait for Mister Right!"
Bye-and-bye, Bye-and-bye,
Don't meet your troubles coming,
And perhaps they'll pass you by.
My prospects now seem rather spare,
No one seems wild my fate to share,
Oh very well, I don't despair,
For someone's going to love me in the sweet Bye-and-Bye!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Somebody loves you now.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Oh Si -- at last!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Listen! It's a dark secret!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: A dark secret? --

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: It's the Governor himself.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Yes. He is consumed with an undying passion for you!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: But he's been asleep every time I met him.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Dreaming of you, little one, dreaming of you!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: It is not possible!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I know it, but it is! From the first moment he saw you, your face has haunted him!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: My face!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Yours, pretty one, yours! That is why no man in New Orleans has dared to propose to you! That is why I - the Whipping Boy, must step back -- erase your image from the tablets of my memory! I see my duty and I do it!

div.stage: (He stalks off tragically L., with LIZETTE following; awed by his manner)
(MARIETTA comes through centre door at bottom. She is in domino and masked. Appears timid and frightened -- MEN enter from ballroom. They are excited and hilarious)

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Ah! A masque!
sp.stage: (Rushing up, grabbing MARIETTA by the arm)
sp.p: Come! Come!
This is not allowed at the Quadroon Ball.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, Messieurs! I beg --

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: No covered faces here!

div.stage: (MARIETTA struggles to retain the mask, which THEY take from her)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh Sire! Have pity -- Oh!

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Ah! The beautiful daughter of Rudolfo!

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Charming! Entrancing! Marietta! Vive Marietta!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: This is unkind, Monsieur. I do not know you.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Oh, but you shall! Come -- dance, sing, laugh!

div.stage: (Taking hold of HER, pulling her towards ballroom)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.stage: (Struggling in the embrace of a MAN)
sp.p: No! No!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh sir, these men --

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Leave us!

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Oh no! 'Tis a privilege of the ball --

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I beg as a favor, leave us --

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Oh, but certainly - later, Mam'selle, later!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh, will you, can you have someone take me back home! I shouldn't have come -- I didn't know --

div.stage: (Enter DICK and BLAKE through C. doors)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Nonsense, those good fellows meant no harm. 'Tis but the license of the ball. Come now, you're under my protection!

div.stage: (He offers his arm to MARIETTA. They start for the ballroom)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Please Marietta, let me take you home.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Ah ha! My friend, I have caught you. You said you were not coming to the ball!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I have just heard from Rudolfo that you were here.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh well! Then I shall stay. As long as my dear friend, my sworn friend is here, all is arranged. Monsieur, your arm. I would dance.

div.stage: (She takes ETIENNE'S arm and they exit into ballroom. MARIETTA laughing over her shoulder at Dick)
(ADAH goes to R., looking into ballroom)

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.p: Well, now we are here, I propose to enjoy myself.
Madam, if you will dance, I shall be walking the floor of Heaven with the evening star on my arm.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: I do not dance tonight.

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.p: Faith -- I'll see another then. (Exits ballroom)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You are not going to dance?

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: He dances first with her. Always before, he opened the ball with me.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Will you favor me?

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: You are kind, but I don't feel like it now.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Come! You should have more spirit! You are beautiful.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Thank you, Monsieur!
But you do not understand the heart of a woman!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh! We disturb --

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Mam'selle, this is no place for you. You are too young. Go away with your good friend.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh! I leave that to you!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Well answered! Why should she be robbed of the joy of life?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Yes, why? I am free. I belong to no one. I shall enjoy everything to the full!

div.stage:
No. 18a "LIVE FOR TODAY"
MARIETTA - CAPTAIN DICK - ETIENNE - ADAH

lg.l: Would you say to the rose
When it blooms to life
Take care you must joyless be
Close your heart, close your lips
To the sunshine bright,
And the breezes wild and free.
Ah! Youth must be youth
In a flower or maid,
Though at evening the petals fall
Ah let me be young while I may today
I may never know joy at all!
Ah, life is sweet
When love is young,
A thrill in the blood like wine,
Then burning glances,
The soul entrances
With rapture almost divine!
Ah! Love is sweet,
Ah! Joy complete
And care is an age away,
Ah! Come then surrender
To love warm and tender
And live for today, just today!
Ah! Ah! Ah! --
I would say to the rose
When it buds to life,
Be guarded, be sweet, be shy,
Yield not your sweets
To each suitor bold
That careless passes by!
Youth is so fleet
Though its day is sweet,
But joy's not the end of all
You dance in the sun so gay all day
But at night the petals fall.

div.stage: (This is a big waltz song and at second refrain entire CHORUS slide in - line F.S. End line, C. - 3rd line, LADIES all dance off at conclusion of song into ballroom)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: 'Tis my duty to see that the King's commands are obeyed. If this woman has shown you the contents of the casquette -- If you have taken her gold - You must wed her.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: But your Excellency does not know all.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: All? What?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: You wish me to wed the Contessa d'Altena?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: The Countessa d'Altena! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Have they kept it from you, Governor?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Kept what from me?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I can say no more. I have private information! I can say no more!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I command you!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Hist! She comes. Do not let her know that I have betrayed her secret. Her secret confided in me in a moment of weakness.

sp.speaker: Silas (Cont'd)
sp.p: Ah Madam! Contessa! Madam!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: You have abused me enough, young man. Don't call me names.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Ssh! The Governor! See how his glances gloat on you!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Mercy!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Come hither, little one.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Oh! Your Excellency!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Fear me not. I know your life's secret!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Oh Excellency! Don't tell anyone.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: It shall rest, between us!
sp.stage: (Governor, looking around, sees SILAS peering in at door)
sp.p: Silas! Here! You!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Did you call?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I wish to have some conversation with this lady!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: What did I tell you!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Take this whistle.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: What for? Do you want soft music for your conversation?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Sit you yonder.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Where is yonder?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Never mind, you go sit on it.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Oh, very well --
Wouldn't you know she was a Countess, Governor -- the way she commands!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: If anyone approaches, whistle.

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Oh, I see -- I'm the whistling boy! Looking out for trouble.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Sit.

div.stage: (LIZETTE is embarrassed, sits on his lap)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Pardon! Pardon! I was just trying it!
sp.stage: (GOVERNOR and LIZETTE sit again -- SILAS whistles)
sp.p: It slipped.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Turn your back!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I will! I will! Can I hear to look? No!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I understand you are not what you seem.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: No woman is what she seems, Governor.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Have you proofs of your parentage?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Proofs? Of course!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Your illustrious father is a very rich man, I understand.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Well, he has a lot of money back of him. I don't know whether it will ever catch up.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Under the circumstances, of course you cannot marry my Whipping Boy.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Not if it pains you, Governor.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: It would pain me very much.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Oh governor.

div.stage: (She throws her arms around the GOVERNOR's neck)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Wait! Perhaps when your father comes, he will not consent. Think of the life I have led.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Well, Governor, you've got nothing on me!

div.stage: (SILAS has come down from landing and is listening eagerly)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Besides, why should my father come to America?

div.stage: (SILAS shows that he is getting anxious)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: But we have sent for him. He has offered ten thousand francs for your return.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Ten thousand francs for my return. That can't be my father!

div.stage:
(SILAS whistles furiously to prevent LIZETTE saying anything more. THEY turn in astonishment. SIR HARRY enters and going up to SILAS, slaps
him heavily on the back. SILAS chokes)

sp.speaker: Sir Harry
sp.p: Well, Sir Whipping Boy, how are you?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I - er --

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Mercy! He's swallowed the whistle.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Give it up - that whistle was solid gold!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Give it up!
I wish I could!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Take him out! Get a pump! He'll choke!

div.stage: (She and SIR HARRY hustle SILAS off R., whistling furiously)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah! Father! How does Louisiana's prospective ruler find himself?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I find myself very uncomfortable. I don't approve of your schemes, and the deeper they go the less I like them.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Oh nonsense! Affairs are progressing finely. You see my popularity -- 'Twill not be long before 'twill be quite safe to declare Louisiana a republic -- we shall rule here.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: But the Governor -- he may bribe your man.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I'll swear to the loyalty of my men. The Governor is safe on the Isle of Pines. My men but await my word to send him where men tell no tales!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Ssh! I'll not listen to it! If it comes out all right, I'm with you -- but -- remember, I don't commit myself.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Oh, my worthy parent --

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh Monsieur! I am glad you persuaded me to come. How I have laughed and enjoyed myself!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I have observed you, Mademoiselle, and I apologize for having disbelieved your statement that you were not the Countessa d'Altera!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I have seen you tonight - the spirit of the people. No lady highly born could have entered as you have into our rustic festivity.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: I don't know that I like that.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Oh, believe me, it has rejoiced me, because if you had really been the Countessa, you would have been far from the reach of Etienne Grandet, but even I may aspire to the daughter of Rudolfo!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Indeed! And how about Adah!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I will sell her tonight, if you will accept my hand and my name.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Sell her! No! No!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Marietta, may I have a word with you please?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You will excuse me -- but -- you will not forget my offer.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You find it gay this ball, my friend?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Very gay, my friend.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You find Adah charming, no?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I find her charming, yes!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Me, I am tired of everything --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Tired?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You are changed tonight - you -- I don't like you any more!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: You have never seemed to like me to any extent, Mademoisselle!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Oh yes. I thought you were a very high character, but you are a coquette!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I -- a coquette?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Yes, I can't have a friend who is a coquette. You are all the same gay, like these Creoles. Yes, drink glass after glass - I saw you --

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It's just the spirit of the place, and yet, there's something the matter with me -- for all I seem gay, I can't feel happy.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Me too!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Shall I tell you about it?

div.stage:
No. 16 SONG -- DICK
"I'M FALLING IN LOVE WITH SOMEONE."

lg.l: I've a very strange feeling
I ne'er felt before
'Tis a kind of a grind
Or depression;
My heart's acting strangely
Feels rather sore,
Or at least it gives me
That impression.
My pulses leap madly
Without any cause,
Believe me I'm telling you
I'm gay without pause
Then and without cause,
My spirits are truly, unruly.
For --
I'm falling in love with someone,
Some one girl -
I'm falling in love with someone,
Head awhirl -
I'm falling in love with someone,
Plain to see,
I'm sure I could love someone madly
If someone would only love me.
I don't mind confessing that I used to scoff
At this sort of sport of flirtation,
I used to believe that I'd never be caught
In this foolish but fond complication;
I'm losing all relish for things that were dear,
I'm looking for trouble and know it,
When someone is near,
I'm feeling quite queer,
But I heartily hope I don't show it.

div.stage: (After first encore, the cries of "Etienne! Vive Etienne! Vive Master of Ceremonies")

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Listen! Hear you all! Hear you all! Silence! According to the long established custom of the Quadroon Ball, any man who wishes to buy, sell or exchange his favorite slave may take advantage of the Cordon Bleu auction!

sp.speaker: Ladies
sp.p: No! No!

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Auction! Auction!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Any woman who has offended by jealousy or loss of charm or any other cause may be put up and sold to the highest bidder.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Blake No! No! Shame! Shame!

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Yes! Yes! Auction! Auction!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Come! Who will buy, sell or exchange! Is no one here brave enough? Well then, I will open the sale with the most beautiful slave in New Orleans!
Adah!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Etienne! Etienne!

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Adah! Auction! Auction!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: A bid! A bid!

sp.speaker: East Indian
sp.p: Five hundred francs! My friends, I am bid five hundred francs for the most beautiful slave in New Orleans!

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: A thousand francs!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: A thousand francs! Come, that is better -- a thousand francs.

sp.speaker: East Indian
sp.p: Twelve hundred!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Do not let him sell me to that man.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Fifteen hundred francs!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Vive the American.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Fifteen hundred francs!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You bid for her!

sp.speaker: East Indian
sp.p: Eighteen hundred francs!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Two thousand.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Come, the game improves! Two thousand bid for La Belle Adah!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: If you bid again, I will never speak to you!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I can't let him sell her to that man.

sp.speaker: East Indian
sp.p: Twenty-two hundred!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Twenty-two hundred. I am bid twenty-two hundred! Going! Going!

div.stage: (DICK hesitates -- ADAH stretches imploring arms to him)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Three thousand!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: East Indian
sp.p: Take her! I'm through!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Three thousand francs. Adah, the most beautiful slave in New Orleans goes to Captain Dick Warrington for three thousand francs! Captain Warrington does not believe in slaves --
Three thousand I am bid. Gentlemen, are you done?

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Going, going, gone -- sold to Captain Richard Warrington for three thousand francs.

div.stage: (ADAH sinks with her face in her hands)

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Ah, beautiful! Beautiful! Captian Dick, my friend, who does not believe in slaves! He makes the highest bid of all! After this sale, the free gift. Behold, I confess I am Marietta d'Altena, sir - you asked me for my hand when you thought I was only Marietta, the daughter of Rudolfo. Now I bestow it upon you!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: No! No!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Yes! Yes!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Mademoiselle, you shall never regret.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I forbid it!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: You forbid? And who are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Come, Marietta. I'll not trust you to keep this promise till tomorrow - we shall be wed tonight.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: A wedding! A wedding!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: We shall end this, the most notable ball with a wedding.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: But these clothes! No! No! I cannot tonight.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Tonight, tonight! Friends, ladies! I leave it to you to find a suitable garments for my bride.

sp.speaker: Nannette, Felice, and Fanchon
sp.p: Yes, yes, we will! Come! Come!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: But - but --

sp.speaker: Nanette
sp.p: You shall have my dress!

sp.speaker: Felice
sp.p: And my veil!

sp.speaker: Fanchon
sp.p: And the orange trees are in blossom!

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.p: Dick, Dick! Be reasonable! What can you do among so many?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: I wouldn't attempt anything rash, Monsieur.

div.stage: (ADAH, DICK and BLAKE left on stage)

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.stage: (Coming down and throwing herself at Dick's feet)
sp.p: My master!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I am not your master. I bought you to set you free.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Free! I -- you will set me free?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Yes, I will make your papers out tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: I - a free woman?
Then I will act like one --
Listen, Monsieur, you would prevent this wedding?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: It must be prevented, the girl is mad! She doesn't realize....

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: On Etienne Grandet's right arm you will find his name!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: His name!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Blake Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Adah
sp.p: I have told you -- make what use of it you will.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Quick, assemble our men!

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.p: I will - it will be a beautiful fight.

div.stage: (SILAS enters from door R., singing -- "I'm Falling in Love with Someone")

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I always fall in love with someone, but nobody falls in love with me. It's pretty soft for Silas here, anyway.
O, see who is coming!

div.stage: No. 17 - SONG -- "IT'S PRETTY SOFT FOR YOU SILAS"

lg.l: King Solomon the Bible says had wives a hundred score,
And still he wasn't satisfied and looked around for more!
He wore a nobby purple suit and an eighteen-karat hat,
And the sweet young things they couldn't resist so
swell a guy as that.
So he used to take a wedding trip most every day or so,
And then he couldn't handle all the brides that tried to go;
And he used to get ten trading stamps for every bale he got.
He kept the bakers baking and the bakings they could bake
To keep filled the royal pantry with the royal wedding cake;
Of course a king's the sort of thing 'most everyone wants to be.
But I don't know that Solomon had very much on me.
For--
It's pretty soft for Silas - that is right,
A regular cinch for Silas, lucky boy!
My winning ways and sunny smile
Has Mr. Solomon skilled a mile.
And it's pretty soft for Silas - Oi Oi --
The Queen of Sheba came to see
What kind of a sort of King was he.
But look at the Queen that fall for me --
It's pretty soft for Silas, lucky boy!
Folks say that old Adonis was the most best looking man,
Of all the lady killer fellows since the world began!
When Venus gave a swell affair, why, this woman didn't care
If the other men they never showed up, if "Ad" was only there
So he went to all the luncheons and the dinners and the teas,
And everybody said he was the smoothest thing in Greece.
He jollied Mrs. Mercury and Frau Denostheses
And danced a dozen waltzes with Frau Hercules.
The fat girls all took anti-fat, the slim ones anti-slim,
They did the best they all could do to make a hit with him,
Of course that social lion thing most everyone wants to be,
But I don't think Adonis he, had very much on me!

div.stage: (At end of song, ALL exit to ballroom)

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Dear me! Dear me! Of course I'll send for the priest if you say so, but this haste! Dear me! Dear me! You have only her word that she is the Contessa. There is another who claims ---

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Nonsense! She is the Contessa d'Altena - Le Grand has seen her often in Italy. Rest easy. I made sure of that before committing myself.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: That's a very fine coat you wear, sir.

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: But I don't like the sleeve!

div.stage: (Seizes ETIENNE'S right sleeve by the cuff and rips it open, disclosing the tattooed arm)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: You know what this means, sir?

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Your Excellency! This man is Bras Pique!! You have seen his name upon his arm. I demand his arrest!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Dear me! Dear me!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: In whose name, sir!

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: In the name of the King of France from whom I bear warrant!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: A bas! The King of France -- I rule here!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: One moment, wait -- we'll settle this thing when the Governor returns. I have no authority, alas. But in the meanwhile you may not know, sir, that for just such emergencies as this -- I have re-established the old order of the whipping boy!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: That's me!!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ha! Ha!

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: He shall take upon himself my son's punishment!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Besides, this man bears too, on his arm the name Bras Pique!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I was only joking. I just had it tattooed to frighten the girls. You told me you had such a well behaved family --

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: Ah ho, guards!
Don't let this man escape -- He is Bras Pique! Take him to the calaboose.
As for you sir, I will meet you where you please, after the wedding.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: We will meet, but it will not be after the wedding.

div.stage: (SILAS runs up C. after DICK. GUARDS push him back)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Oh Governor, Governor, now don't fall asleep. I think something is going to happen to me. Oh, Governor, save me, what are they going to do with me?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I don't know, I am sure -- the penalty for piracy is hanging. Maybe I can get you out of that!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: You will?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Yes, -- I'll get them to shoot you, it's quicker.

div.stage: (TWO GAURDS come down and seize SILAS, pulling him up C.)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: Mercy ---

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Mercy! Did you have mercy when you tried to foist that chromo off on me as the Contessa d'Altena? Away with him!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Si! Si -- where are you going?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: I'm not going, I'm being took.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Where are you being tooken to?

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: To the Calaboose.

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Then I'll go with you. I don't care for that fat Governor!

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: All right Lizette, come ahead. I don't care what becomes of me now!

sp.speaker: Lizette
sp.p: Call me Lizzie.

div.stage: (GUARDS exit through C. door with SILAS followd by LIZETTE)

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: I suppose I shall have to take the law into my own hands - as long as you refuse - Forward March.

div.stage: (Enter MARIETTA and GIRLS in bridal clothes)

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Oh, how charming! How sweet!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: I beg of you - give me a few moments alone!

sp.speaker: Girls
sp.p: Assuredly! Come -- the bride must have a few moments - come.

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.stage: (Enters from C. door, coming down to Marietta)
sp.p: Mademoiselle! Mademoiselle! You are making a great mistake!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.p: Captain Dick has set Adah free!

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Set her free?

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.p: Yes - and this man you are going to marry is Bras Pique.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: Etienne?

sp.speaker: Blake
sp.p: Yes, Etienne Grandet. Our men are on the way. In a matter of minutes, we'll have him and his crew.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: He set Adah free? Oh what a fool I've been.
Let me pass.

sp.speaker: Guards
sp.p: Our orders are that no one is to leave until after the wedding.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: But there will be no wedding, stupid!

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: We have our orders.

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: I am so unhappy - so unhappy.

sp.speaker: Dick

lg.l: Oh sweet mystery of life, at last I've found thee
Ah! I know at last the secret of it all!
All the longing, seeking, striving, waiting, yearning,
The fond hopes, the joy and foolish tears
that fall --

sp.stage: (MARIETTA has risen and is listening intently)
(CAPTAIN DICK is seen cautiously entering at window from balcony)

lg.l: For 'tis love and love alone the world is seeking,
And 'tis love and love alone can satisfy;
This the answer, this the end and all of living!
For it is love alone that rules for aye.

div.stage: (He comes downstairs signing, his arms outstretched to MARIETTA. She joins in the song and THEY sing it through together)
(At the close she is in his arms)
(Enter ETIENNE in wedding clothes followed by GUESTS)

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.p: What's this? My bride?

sp.speaker: Marietta
sp.p: No No Monsieur he has sang my song, the prophecy has come true.

div.stage: (SILAS and LIZETTE enter followed by BLAKE and HIS MEN)

sp.speaker: Silas
sp.p: They have reloosed me! The have reloosed me!

sp.speaker: Etienne
sp.stage: (Runs upstairs but is stopped by OTHERS of BLAKE'S MEN)
sp.p: The game's well played, Monsieur, you win.

sp.speaker: Dick
sp.p: Let him go! I have won, all I want in this world.

div.stage: (Takes MARIETTA in his arms as ALL sing DREAM MELODY, possible "ZING ZING" for curtain)
